awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Leadership: Increasing Leaders from Historically Under-Represented Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
In this increasing complex world, STEM leaders must have a broader education than science, technology, and engineering to be successful in addressing the leadership challenges required to solve the technological challenges facing the world. Rising leaders need to have a grounding in the social and behavioral sciences and an appreciation for the cultural, economic, political, and educational differences of the people and communities who will use and/or be affected by the STEM approaches they will be developing. Additionally, addressing the underrepresentation of marginalized groups in leadership positions within the US STEM enterprise is vital to ensuring that the nation has a robust and diverse STEM workforce.

This conference proposal will deliver a three-day workshop to document and learn from a multidecadal perspective the following: 1) characteristics of leaders from underrepresented groups in STEM, 2) transformative efforts that increased representation of diverse STEM leaders across various institutions (academia, public sector, non-profit sector, and private sector), 3) innovative diversity and inclusion perspectives from current leaders, 4) effective/emerging strategies regarding the development of next-generation leaders from underrepresented groups, and 5) approaches for the integration of STEM with social sciences to facilitate processes for a diversity of early and mid-career scientists and engineers to gain leadership positions.

While the number of leaders from underrepresented groups (URGs) has increased modestly over time, this increase has lagged the increase of individuals from URGs in STEM workplaces, which themselves do not yet reflect the demographics of the Nation. This workshop has the potential of affecting various types of institutions that have lagged in utilizing fully the repository of national talent by involving policy makers at the highest level as well as strong leaders who can speak not only to the value of diversity but can also articulate the work and the processes behind their stories of success, thereby illuminating possible paths forward.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Workshop on Leadership: Increasing Leaders from Historically Under-Represented Groups

October 29, 2021; January 6 and 20, 2022: 1:00 pm to 5:30 pm EDT 

The Leadership Workshop, hosted by Penn State University and Intersections SBD Consulting and supported by a grant from the National Science Foundation, was organized to advance innovative leadership strategies that encourage the full participation of women, underrepresented groups, and persons with disabilities in leadership roles in the scientific and engineering enterprise. The Workshop brought together leaders from STEM fields who represented all career levels and many historically underrepresented groups to share their professional experiences and provide illustrations of lessons learned and strategies to reflect on best practices, propose new strategies to advance diversity, equity, accessibility, and inclusion in STEM. The shared experiences provided a rare opportunity to envision future national strategies to have diverse leadership in STEM fields.  In addition, the Workshop provided information on how more members of underrepresented groups can successfully transition to leadership positions in all areas of our society where science, technology, engineering, and mathematics are important components. In the United States, there is an urgent need to have leaders in science and engineering that ideally is as diverse as the population of the country to have a competitive and diverse workforce. The advancement of diverse leadership teams in science and engineering will greatly benefit the Nation as expected discoveries in science and development of advanced technologies will directly benefit the society.

Workshop presentations can be seen under each presenters name on the Speaker tab at web page https://leadershipinstem.psu.edu/ or they can be found on YouTube by searching by speaker first and last name AND Leadership (e.g., John Slaughter AND Leadership) 

The goals of the workshop were:

  • Engage past and present leaders to brainstorm ideas of leadership development for people from URGs.
  • Determine what NSF and other institutions currently do to encourage the development of leaders from URGs.
  • Identify and highlight examples of institutions where diversity has become successfully 
    integrated into institutional culture and examine the role of the leadership team.
  • Listen to the narratives of how leaders from URGs reached leadership positions to identify aspects of leadership that can be taught.
  • Brainstorm on ways to gather and disseminate these stories.
  • Identify formal and informal educational pathways that provide potential leaders with social and behavioral science as well as an appreciation for the cultural, economic, political, and educational differences of the people and communities.
  • Examine the role of leaders who are not primarily in STEM, but in media, education, politics, and business.

The workshop organizing committee members are noted for their lifetime advocacy for diversity, equality, and inclusion:

  • Lydia Villa-Komaroff, Ph.D. Founder and President Intersections SBD Consulting. One of the early pioneers in recombinant DNA technology, her career spans molecular biology, academic administration, and business.
  • Jose D. Fuentes, Ph.D.  Professor of Atmospheric Science, Penn State University. Chair, NSF Committee on Equal Opportunity in Science and Engineering (CEOSE)
  • Willie Pearson, Jr.  Ph.D. Professor of Sociology, Georgia Tech. His books, monographs, and journal articles on underrepresented groups in science and engineering have influenced national policy.
  • John B. Slaughter, Ph.D., Professor of Education and Engineering, USC. The first Black Chancellor of The University of Maryland, College Park; first Black Director of NSF. His long and distinguished career spans academia, the Federal Government, the nonprofit sector, and business.

Modified by: Jose D Fuentes
